oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aims of the patrons of husbandry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This full-page clipping from the Grange Outlook contains an address prepared by W.H. Jackson for the Farmers' meeting at Manchester, July 4 1874. Many of the nascent issues that would mold populist sentiments are outlined. These include dealing with "middlemen," curtailing the power of railroads to charge discriminatory rates, and reforming public education.

The farmers' movement began with the Grange of the Order of the Patrons of Husbandry. Steeped in masonic roots, this organization sought to spread information and pool resources in a spirit of cooperation amongst farmers. Their surviving publications highlight such efforts as they become politically and socially charged.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Newspapers; Agriculture--Political aspects; Agricultural literature--Publishing
